applications.fundingAsk: {"blocks":[{"key":"2aq4k","text":"Bridging Web2 Developers to Arbitrum Through Community and dApps","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":64,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"t5e6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dnfa2","text":"Europe hosts a vast pool of  Web2 developers eager to explore Web3. The \"European Arbitrum Developer Workshops\" will accelerate their transition to Arbitrum by combining weekly networking events with hands-on dApp development. Partnering with the Erasmus Greece Student Network (10,000+ students), we’ll launch a pilot in Athens using team recreational activities like football to foster connections and collaboration, with plans to scale across European universities and beyond.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":72,"length":39,"style":"BOLD"},{"offset":246,"length":51,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75f01","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dqq65","text":"Unlike standard workshops, this initiative uses interactive, recurring events to foster sustained engagement. It builds local communities and creates a sustainable pipeline of developers contributing to Arbitrum’s ecosystem.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":109,"style":"BOLD"},{"offset":141,"length":83,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6lkj0","text":"Structure & Format","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":18,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"etb9e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bdl7q","text":"This 4-month cohort (3 months of training + 1 month of building) will onboard developers through collaborative learning and community engagement.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":5,"length":14,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"esjes","text":"Pilot & Weekly Agenda","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":21,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"74jou","text":"Recreational Activities (1 hour): Casual events fostering collaboration—e.g., football in the Athens pilot, with future iterations offering more team activities to ensure a broader appeal.  Free participation (vs. the typical €25 cost providing an incentive for participants).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":34,"style":"ITALIC"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bdpgo","text":"Developers' Meetup (1 hour after each game) – Hands-on workshops on Arbitrum development, covering:","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":43,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4happ","text":"Introduction to Arbitrum & Layer-2 Scaling – Enhancing Ethereum scalability.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fcgre","text":"Smart Contract Development on Arbitrum – Writing efficient contracts using Stylus.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cld6o","text":"Development Tools – Arbitrum-specific tools.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b2drv","text":"Libraries & SDKs – Integrating APIs to simplify dApp building.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d7i3l","text":"Building Scalable dApps – Best practices for efficiency and sustainability.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cljgd","text":"This program will empower developers to build, network, and contribute to Arbitrum’s open-source ecosystem.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4cuig","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"38a80","text":"Student Engagement\nErasmus students are known for actively engaging in extracurricular activities and workshops, as it’s integral to their student experience. This program will encourage that involvement, making it a natural fit within their learning and professional growth journeys. By combining social activities with technical workshops, we ensure that students not only gain technical skills but also strengthen community ties and work on real-world projects.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":19,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"qpgd","text":"Expansion Strategy","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":18,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ec3at","text":"Beyond Erasmus, we’ll partner with universities and bootcamps to reach more Web2 developers. Expansion with other cities in Greece will follow and then a European expansion, creating developers in Europe eager to build on Arbitrum.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f5sc8","text":"Impact Goals","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":12,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3povs","text":"Engagement: Onboard 50+ developers; tracked by attendance and community growth (on Discord).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":10,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"24edr","text":"Skills: Train 10+ developers in smart contracts by Month 3; measured by GitHub activity.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":6,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fphuf","text":"dApps:  5+ MVP dApps Deploy real world use by Month 4; verified via testnet/mainnet.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":5,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cpnqq","text":"Contributions: Engage 5+ developers in Arbitrum open-source projects; assessed by pull requests.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":13,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b8eon","text":"Retention & Support","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":19,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bgk","text":"Post-program, a mentorship network and alumni community will sustain engagement. Participants will access job boards, collaboration opportunities, and a Demo Day to showcase dApps—potentially earning grants for standout projects. Regular attendees will gain priority for career opportunities, ensuring long-term ties to Arbitrum.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cdkio","text":"This is a scalable model that will empower developers, build community, and drive Arbitrum’s growth through practical contributions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7ngr0","text":"The Arbitrum Stylus Accelerator Program (ASAP) is a talent accelerator program designed to rapidly scale the developer base within the Arbitrum ecosystem by partnering with local innovation hubs to train young, aspiring developers across Africa. The program will be launched through a pilot phase in Nigeria, where 4 top hubs across 4 different cities in major geopolitical zones will host a total of 100 developers to undergo a three-week training and hackathon program. This approach ensures that developers not only learn the theoretical aspects of blockchain technology but also gain practical experience by building real-world applications using Arbitrum Stylus.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":285,"length":22,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

The project includes a series of workshops, a hackathon, and a growth program to support the deployment of decentralized applications (dApps) on Arbitrum.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":4,"length":56,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"a94s","text":"Wayfinders is a Global brand founded by Spike Collects and Roger Caneda, focused on bridging the gap between Web2 gamers and the Web3 ecosystem. Our flagship initiative is a thriving Counter Strike 2 (CS2) club on FACEIT, with over 3,750 monthly active Web2 gamers.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":183,"length":37,"style":"BOLD"},{"offset":232,"length":32,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d422i","text":"Over the last 4 months, we’ve already paid out more than $30,000 in crypto rewards to players in our community, demonstrating strong user engagement and real world Web2 value delivery.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":14,"length":8,"style":"BOLD"},{"offset":38,"length":44,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"272or","text":"This grant proposal seeks to scale our infrastructure by expanding tournament offerings, activating IRL events gloablly and increasing Web3 onboarding through education, quests, and content, all built on Arbitrum.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":204,"length":8,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1g6mj","text":"Key Components:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":15,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2vq20","text":"Tournaments & On-Chain Incentives: Daily and weekly CS2 tournaments with prize payouts in $ARB or USDC via Arbitrum.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":34,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fi7ll","text":"Gamified Onboarding: Wayfinders Points system rewards users for engaging, learning, and playing. Redeemable for raffles and prizes.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":20,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9fl4s","text":"Educational Content: Weekly AMAs, beginner guides, and 24/7 Discord support for onboarding users to Arbitrum tools and wallets.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":20,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9dsp5","text":"Community & IRL Events: Live game nights, local tournaments, and meetups across Argentina and Brazil.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":23,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dgual","text":"Data-Driven Impact: Using built-in analytics from FACEIT and Discord to track wallet creation, retention, and Web3 activity.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":19,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6oip7","text":"Wayfinders will also support ecosystem growth by integrating and promoting Raijin.gg and Raijin Games, a key player within the XAI ecosystem. As part of this partnership, Raijin branding and messaging will be featured throughout our content, tournaments, and community channels, helping drive visibility and adoption through steam powered games!","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":345,"style":"ITALIC"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6dpqj","text":"While Arbitrum continues to lead globally as a top Layer 2 network, it still has very little presence in Canada — a country that’s home to some of the most active blockchain builders, developers, and investors in the world. This is a big gap, and an even bigger opportunity.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fjs5f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"696is","text":"To kick off Arbitrum’s growth in the region, we’re proposing a strategic first step: sponsoring The Futurist Conference, Canada’s largest blockchain event and one of the most respected globally. The conference is the flagship of Canada Crypto Week, a major gathering of crypto projects, builders, and ecosystem leaders from across Canada and North America.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":96,"length":23,"style":"BOLD"},{"offset":229,"length":18,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6o2kr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8bfg","text":"By participating at the Silver Sponsorship level, Arbitrum will not only get a speaking slot on the main stage, but also strong brand visibility throughout the week — on signage, media, volunteer shirts, social channels, and more. This gives Arbitrum the chance to show up in a meaningful way and start building awareness, relationships, and momentum in a region where it’s currently underrepresented.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":24,"length":24,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"155en","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5n1m3","text":"Why The Futurist Conference?","type":"header-two","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":28,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2rac2","text":"Strategic Timing for the DAO
With the Arbitrum DAO’s growing focus on global presence, this is the perfect time to establish visibility in Canada — a key but currently underserved region in the ecosystem.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":28,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9lcm4","text":"A Launchpad for Long-Term Growth
This isn’t just about one event — it’s the start of a long-term effort to grow Arbitrum’s footprint across Canada through dev engagement, partnerships, and community building.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":32,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ehi65","text":"Canada’s Largest Blockchain Event
The Futurist Conference is the biggest and most recognized blockchain event in Canada, drawing thousands of attendees from around the world.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":33,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2pdhp","text":"Part of Canada Crypto Week
It anchors a week-long series of events that attracts the full spectrum of the crypto ecosystem — developers, founders, investors, protocols, and media.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":26,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cl9j2","text":"Audience That Aligns with Arbitrum
The event brings together Arbitrum’s ideal audience: Ethereum developers, DeFi protocols, gaming projects, and high-TVL builders looking for scalable solutions.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":34,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aoil0","text":"Strong Brand Exposure & Community Entry Point
Sponsorship provides a speaking slot, booth presence, and extensive logo placement — positioning Arbitrum as a serious player in the Canadian scene.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":45,"style":"BOLD"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"52jb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"famtd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

applications.fundingAsk: {"blocks":[{"key":"891ka","text":"The Arbitrum DAO Creator Economy is a content initiative designed to make Arbitrum Orbit AppChains more accessible to everyday users. While most content about Arbitrum focuses on price speculation or developer tools, this project creates 50 short-form videos (3-8 minutes each) that showcase the consumer experience of AppChains like EDU Chain, XAI Games, ApeChain with clear calls to action for onboarding. In addition to producing content, Arbitrum DAO natives will have the opportunity to create videos through an ARB bounty program, expanding participation. We will also run bi-weekly engagement-driven workshops featuring AppChain teams, live feedback loops, and an incentive program where users earn XP, converting into ARB rewards. Through this initiative, we are activating the Arbitrum community, turning passive users into contributors, and building a self-sustaining creator economy that drives long-term adoption. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

- Current activity signals: 120,292+ monthly redemption/withdrawal requests (showing strong repeat intent)
- Lifetime reward value processed (cumulative): $430K+
- Outcome type: high-frequency engagement loops + proven operational capability to manage incentives at scale.

(We can provide screenshots/links and platform analytics exports as attachments during submission.)

applications.name: OLA GG x Arbitrum in Brazil
applications.grantAmount:
OLA Guild Games has extensive experience executing content campaigns, tournaments, and creator-led activations across both Web2 and Web3, with measurable impact. Below are two of the most relevant examples:

Example 1: OLA CUP x Arbitrum Gaming Activation (Previous Arbitrum Grant)

OLA GG successfully executed a prior Arbitrum-funded initiative focused on community-driven adoption and gaming activations across Latin America. The campaign combined creator content, online tournaments, and mission-based engagement to onboard users into Arbitrum gaming experiences helping Wildcard with its launch.

Key metrics and outcomes:

29,000+ users onboarded into Arbitrum-related gaming activities (Wildcard Wishlists/Download)

300+ creator content pieces published (short-form videos, posts, gameplay content)

4,000,000+ total impressions generated across social platforms

60,000+ tracked clicks to Arbitrum-related landing pages and experiences

Multiple online tournaments and Game Nights executed with consistent participation

100% milestone completion, with KPIs exceeded and full reporting delivered to the Arbitrum Foundation

This initiative demonstrated OLA GG’s ability to deliver measurable adoption, manage grant funding responsibly, and execute at scale within the Arbitrum ecosystem.

Example 2: Large-Scale Gaming Events & Creator Activations (LATAM)

OLA GG has executed and participated in major gaming events and creator activations throughout Latin America, including Gamescom LATAM, Brasil Game Show, Argentina Game Show, and Gamergy Mexico. These initiatives blended IRL tournaments, creator coverage, and digital amplification.

Key metrics and outcomes:

200,000+ people reached through live events and online amplification

10,000+ players engaged through tournaments, Game Nights, and community challenges

Execution of Brazil’s largest Web3 creator house, producing continuous livestreams and short-form gameplay content during the event period having +200 brazilian creators visiting the house.

These activations closely mirror the structure of the proposed project combining IRL trust, creators, and competitive play and validate OLA GG’s capability to execute high-impact, repeatable onboarding initiatives.

applications.name: DePropFirm
applications.grantAmount: No, We are fundamentally a DeFi project, but since we do not provide real financial services or execute real trades on the market, our activity is closer to a simulated trading environment — similar to a skill-based game. All trading operations are simulated on-chain through smart contracts, without real market exposure. This makes our structure more aligned with the Gaming Platform category than traditional DeFi, as users interact in a risk-free, gamified trading system built to train and evaluate performance transparently on-chain.

Executed a two-week content campaign across Twitter and TikTok that onboarded over 100 new gamers through tracked link clicks and creator-led posts. The campaign achieved 50,000+ impressions and a conversion rate of 12%, helping Solplex reach a wider Web2 gaming audience.

2. Mantle Game Fest – Livestream Activation
Hosted and promoted the Mantle Game Fest across Twitch, averaging 300+ total live viewers and driving high engagement through event-based content. The activation boosted awareness for Mantle’s ecosystem titles and demonstrated the effectiveness of creator-led conversion campaigns within blockchain gaming.

These experiences demonstrate my ability to run high-performing, conversion-focused campaigns that not only attract attention but also translate into measurable ecosystem growth, directly aligning with Arbitrum’s goals for user acquisition and retention.

applications.name: Arbitrium YGG Play Summit - Wolves Manila Creator House
applications.grantAmount:
Yes, Wolves has organized and executed several large-scale creator and content activations that closely mirror the scope of this proposal. Below are the two most relevant examples:

1. Arbitrum x Wolves Creator House at GDC 2025
In partnership with Arbitrum, Wolves produced a week-long creator activation during Game Developers Conference (GDC) that featured livestreams, interviews, and content coverage of the Arbitrum ecosystem games.

Deliverables: 20+ pieces of video content and over 10 livestream sessions

Reach: 500,000+ organic impressions across YouTube, X, and Discord

Engagement: Average watch time of 2.8 minutes per clip, with 8–10% engagement rate

Outcome: Strengthened Arbitrum’s brand visibility among developers and Web3 gaming audiences, generating community growth and new ecosystem awareness

2. CreatorDEN Manila at YGG Play Summit 2024
Wolves organized and hosted a live creator house and multi-day filming event featuring top Web3 gaming creators.

Deliverables: 30+ short-form videos, vlogs, and livestreams produced on-site

Reach: 1.2M+ total impressions across social platforms

Audience: Coverage across creators from the US, EU, Brazil, and APAC, with combined audiences exceeding 2M followers

Outcome: Established Wolves as a leading creator activation partner for Web3 gaming, creating measurable lift for ecosystem partners and games featured at the event

These activations demonstrate Wolves’ ability to plan, execute, and deliver measurable results through creator-led content and live media coverage. The Wolves Manila Creator House for Arbitrum builds directly upon these proven frameworks, with additional layers of analytics and campaign tracking through our Kizuna community platform to measure engagement, reach, and traffic across all deliverables.

applications.name: Tollan Universe User Acquisition Campaign
applications.grantAmount:
Yes. Tollan Universe has already run two successful creator-led seasons focused on growing the community and driving activity on Arbitrum.

Season 1 was fully self-funded and brought in 2,567 wallet-connected players. The prize pool grew from $3,000 to $7,600 just from player activity. Players logged nearly 20,000 runs and averaged over 10 hours of playtime. All growth came from creators like Tempest, Wayfinders, Soltek and strong Discord coordination.

Season 2 is live now. In the 7 days, nearly 14,500 players joined and generated over 3.5 million transactions on Arbitrum. The prize pool jumped from $4,000 to $7,000+ in just a week. We worked with creators like Crazy Teddy, Tempest, and Wayfinders - all previous Arbitrum grant recipients.

During our Season 1 we were also featured on largest indie games showcase with 250k live viewers (OTK Games Expo 2025). 
These campaigns show we can drive strong creator results, convert users, and deliver real impact to the Arbitrum ecosystem.

applications.name: Premier Amateur Esports Exhibition Hall for Thailand: MAYG
applications.applicant: MAYG by Peeking Duck Studios Ltd
applications.grantAmount:
Yes. 
We have extensive live tournament and venue set-up at a world class 5 star hotel and regulated casino levels. I was the founding producer in charge of all aspects of running this regional poker tour, as well as the poker room head for marketing and set-up in Macau from 2007-2010. I was the regional director of Asia for Pokerstars. Seasons 1-3. This included online and live player registration, hotel and venue negotiation and rates, film and media coordination, TV production, regulatory approval, staff training, tournament format and scheduling, media PR messaging, and promotions. I had a tournament director that managed the live tournament.  

As an example for season 1: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asia_Pacific_Poker_Tour
24-26 Aug 2007, Hyatt Manila, Manila. Entrants: 255 Total Prize oool awarded: $599,250	
28-30 Sep 2007, Sheraton Walker-Hill Hotel, Seoul. Entrants:185 Total Prize pool U$432,729
22-27 Nov 2007,Grand Waldo, Taipa, Macau, Entrants: 352  Total Prize Pool awarded $809,600
13-16 Dec 2007 The Star Sydney, Australia, Entrants: 561 Total Prize Pool awarded $2,580,286

This set the operational foundation for the tournament which continues today to run for over 16 years, and awarded over 90M USD in prizepool. 

These also included online qualifiers, and additionally for a permanent venue, I had set-up and operated the Pokerstars Live Macau poker room of 22 tables, including a monthly Macau tournament which routinely had over 300 players. https://www.macaubusiness.com/david-jung/

Why this is relevant was that Texas Hold'em poker at the time was not known in Asia, it was non-existent as a mainstream game and not never niche with local markets. This required a lot of in person education as the purpose of the live events was to create awareness, but also to onboard players into payment solutions that would work for the online site as well as set-up marketing channels and create trust that we were a legitimate operation and that poker was actually a game of skill. The metric is that this kicked off the poker boom in Asia and it has never looked back since. 

For esports- I was a pioneering generation and was part of 1st World Cyber Games in 2001 in Seoul. At the event I was mainly the head of the Canadian team and was the tournament director for the Starcraft Broodwar event. At the time WCG was sponsored by Samsung. From 2000-2001 I assisted in running the Canada based qualifiers in Toronto and Vancouver as well. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Cyber_Games. At the time again, esports was not big internationally outside of Korea, so the metric is that this was part of the greater movement that eventually became the global esports scene. 

As someone who has been through 2 transitional periods in 2000's and 2010's for esports and poker, I do feel that web3 gaming is at the same point and what is critical is not just a hit game that represents that innovation, but also in-person tournaments and onboard was especially key in the educational and community aspect that kept on growing stronger and stronger regardless of market or media coverage. 

Social media can amplify messages and create awareness, but when it is a transitional period, in my experience it is necessary to build trust through in person tournaments and events that create an unbreakable community. The benefit that we have now is that with our venue and regular events, the social media can directly communicate to potential players at a scale like never before.  But a single onboarded player in a live event can be fully onboarded and act as an educational node for at least 10 others and so on and so forth. 

The reason why many brands do not do this is because their game does not require such a high level of education and also the marketing channels are already quite suitable for their marketing message. With the high degree of a lack of trust and by fully onboarding players can really engage in the full spectrum of the benefits of web3. Things like wallet abstraction or hiding the blockchain functionality is necessary because it doesn't help for existing marketing channels like Steam where there are restrictions or decreases confusion.  As this proposal is related to us launching our own game successfully, this is a central piece to our launch plans as we would like this venue to be the center of web3 PC gaming for competitive games in the future for Asia as whole. 

As a seasoned gaming and live operator executive, our metrics really will come down to the views continue to growing organically as the reputation of the venue increases. 
But we have participated as the 'game content' in past Arbitrum questbook grants to others and through amplification had received +50,000 sign ups via game platform questing (to be clear, we did not receive the grant and were simply included in the grantee's metrics).

applications.applicant: Credify Market (Affidex Lab) — pre‑incorporation; entity formation planned in Dubai Free Zone
applications.fundingAsk:
Credify Market Crypto Cities pilot on Arbitrum

What we’re building

An identity‑first e‑commerce marketplace on Arbitrum where:
•Sellers are verified off‑chain and receive a non‑transferable VendorPass SBT that gates listings and seller actions (no PII on‑chain).
• Buyers pay with USDC held in a smart‑contract escrow; funds are released on delivery/acceptance, with an admin refund path under policy.
• UX is mainstream‑friendly via gasless checkout (EIP‑4337 paymaster).
• City‑level adoption is measured publicly (vendors, buyers, GMV, dispute rate, escrow events).

Live foundation on Arbitrum One

• VendorPass (SBT): 0xdFff9e85b27FAfe73B25DBc1393844C18258Ed40
• EscrowUSDC: 0x9543E639A3DF48851d3Baae90754083E8B1A20CC
• USDC: 0xaf88d065e77c8cC2239327C5EDb3A432268e5831
• App wired to Arbitrum + USDC, with escrow flow integrated.

Implementation plan (what the grant funds)

Workstream A — Product & Engineering

•Paymaster (gasless checkout)
•Prototype → production using an EIP‑4337 paymaster (e.g., Pimlico/Biconomy). Sponsor createOrder/release flows with strict per‑user/per‑tx limits and allowlists. Fallback to standard txs if quota exceeded.
• Deliverables: working sponsorship on mainnet, rate‑limit service, logs/alerts, and UX copy for gasless checkout.
• Subgraph + public dashboard
• Index VendorPass + Escrow events (OrderCreated/Released/Refunded), compute city KPIs (vendors onboarded, verified buyers, GMV, dispute rate, escrow tx count, paymaster share).
•Deliverables: subgraph, public dashboard URL, monthly reports.
• On/off‑ramp & payouts (integration)
• Integrate an Arbitrum‑compatible on/off‑ramp for merchant settlement (partner to be confirmed), add payout guidance and merchant settings.
• Deliverables: partner integration checklist, merchant docs, test settlement flow.
• Seller & admin tools
• Vendor dashboard (status, listings, orders), admin runbooks & UI for refunds/SBT revocation, and incident response (refund SLAs, dispute escalation).
• Deliverables: vendor/admin UIs, SOPs for support, dispute logging.
• Security & QA
•Unit/integration tests for escrow/SBT; static analysis (Slither), peer review; lightweight audit prior to scale; monitoring & alerting.
• Deliverables: test coverage report, audit notes, monitoring playbook.

Workstream B — City Operations (Singapore & Dubai)

•Merchant acquisition & onboarding
•Target SMEs (electronics, fashion, health/beauty, compliant age‑restricted goods). Provide KYC credits, assisted onboarding, listing imports, and training.
• Deliverables: 150+ verified vendors (SG ≈80 / DXB ≈70), LOIs, onboarding materials.
• Buyer growth & activations
• City‑specific campaigns (co‑working/community partners), escrow education, early‑merchant perks (0% fee on first $500 GMV), referral ($25 after first sale).
• Deliverables: activation calendar, campaign briefs, conversion metrics.
• Support & disputes
• Operate refund/release SLAs; publish an incident response playbook; enforce SBT revocation for policy breaches.
• Deliverables: monthly incident summary, average resolution times, dispute rate <3%.

Workstream C — Reporting, Privacy & Compliance

•Public transparency
• Monthly city reports and live dashboard: vendors, buyers, GMV (USDC), dispute rate, escrow events, gasless share, CAC→GMV funnel snapshots.
• Privacy & data handling
• No PII on‑chain. KYC off‑chain via vendor; DPA in place; clear retention & deletion; PDPA/PDPL‑aware • Privacy Notice. SBT metadata only includes generic verification status and policy version.
• Governance readiness
• Prepare dispute‑resolution v2 (DAO‑weighted voting) after pilot, and an Orbit‑chain path if regional compliance/data segmentation requires L3.

Milestones & targets (summary)

•M1 (Weeks 1–4): Singapore launch; 25 vendors; paymaster prototype; ≥$25k GMV; prelim dashboard.
•M2 (Weeks 5–8): Dubai launch; +25 vendors; cumulative 60 vendors; ≥$75k GMV.
• M3 (Months 3–4): 100 vendors; ≥$150k GMV; public dashboard live; dispute rate ≤3%.
• M4 (Months 5–6): 150 vendors; ≥$300k GMV; retention >50%; partner integrations; final report.

KPIs the grant unlocks

•Vendors ≥150; Buyers ≥1,500; GMV ≥$300k; Disputes <3%; Escrow events ≥2,000; Vendor activation ≥60%; measurable gasless adoption and improved buyer conversion.

Why this is a strong Orbit fit

• Business‑driven adoption with measurable city‑level economic outcomes.
• Reusable credential + escrow primitives that other Arbitrum apps can compose with.
• Clear sustainability: platform fee + subscriptions, partner co‑marketing, and a repeatable “city playbook” for expanding Crypto Cities on Arbitrum.

applications.name: - Cuts onboarding time: One place to add Orbit networks (EIP-3085) and import tokens (EIP-747) reduc...
applications.fundingAsk:
This MVP, rescoped directly from your feedback, delivers a simplified dashboard that aggregates multiple Orbit chains in one place, lists verified RPC endpoints and canonical explorer links, supports wallet onboarding via EIP-3085 (Add Network) and EIP-747 (Import Token) with copyable fallbacks, provides a lightweight cross-Orbit address/transaction resolver that returns the correct chain hit with a deep link, and displays basic RPC health badges (up/down, block-lag threshold, and p95 latency). It is not a replacement for per-chain explorers; it complements them by removing discovery and setup friction.

Implementation plan (MVP):

- Registry & validation: Define a JSON schema for chain entries; implement a small Node.js validator that checks structure and verifies RPCs via eth_chainId and eth_blockNumber.

- Health signals: Use scheduled probes (e.g., GitHub Actions) to sample each listed RPC, compute block-lag (>10 blocks flagged) and p95 latency, and publish a small health.json consumed by the UI (no stateful backend).

- Resolver: Build a fan-out resolver with per-RPC timeouts; for addresses, check eth_getTransactionCount / eth_getCode to indicate observed activity; for transactions, use eth_getTransactionByHash and deep-link to the matching chain’s explorer.

- Frontend: Implement a minimal Next.js/TypeScript UI with chain cards (Add Network, Import Token, health badge) and a resolve page; include copyable config fallbacks when wallet methods aren’t supported.

- CI/CD & deploy: Add schema and endpoint checks that fail PRs on malformed entries or dead/slow RPCs; ship a static build to Vercel/Netlify/GitHub Pages and provide Docker/Compose for one-click self-host.

applications.fundingAsk:
Orbit Telegram SDK: Social-Native Cross-Chain Infrastructure for 900M Users
We're building the first Telegram-native SDK that makes Orbit chains accessible through bot commands and Mini Apps, bringing cross-chain functionality to Telegram's 900M users without requiring them to leave their trusted social environment.
Core Product:
A developer SDK and bot infrastructure enabling seamless Orbit chain interactions within Telegram through:

Non-Custodial Telegram Wallet Bot: Users create MPC-sharded wallets via /create_wallet, manage assets across all Orbit chains, and execute transactions through simple commands—all without custody risk.
Intent-Based Cross-Chain Execution: Natural language commands like /swap 10 USDC on ArbitrumNova to ETH on Xai trigger Universal Intent Engine, with solvers competing for best execution in under 3 seconds.
Mini Apps Development SDK: TypeScript library enabling any Telegram Mini App to integrate Orbit cross-chain functionality with a few lines of code, dramatically expanding the developer funnel beyond traditional web3 builders.
Group-Based Liquidity Pools: Telegram communities can collectively pool funds for better solver rates, manage cross-chain treasuries, and coordinate through social consensus mechanisms.
Social Growth Mechanics: Built-in referral tracking, group leaderboards, and shareable transaction receipts that create viral loops for Orbit adoption.

Target Impact:

500K+ cross-chain transactions via Telegram in 5 months
50K+ wallet addresses created
20+ solvers optimized for Telegram intents
10+ independent Mini Apps using the SDK

This transforms Orbit chains from technical infrastructure into socially-native products accessible to hundreds of millions of crypto-curious users, particularly in emerging markets where Telegram dominates.

applications.name: Our project directly aligns with the Arbitrum ecosystem vision of driving DeFi dominance, strengthen...
applications.fundingAsk:
Project Idea & Implementation Plan

We are building a Cross-Chain Solver & UX Dashboard for Orbit Chains, designed to strengthen the Arbitrum Orbit ecosystem by empowering solvers, simplifying cross-chain user interactions, and providing ecosystem-wide analytics. The platform directly supports the Universal Intent Engine by lowering barriers for solver onboarding, enabling one-click cross-chain transactions, and delivering transparency tools that increase trust and adoption.

Core Components

Solver Infrastructure Tools

Onboarding Module: Guided registration, liquidity provisioning, and validator setup for new solvers.

Monitoring Tools: Real-time dashboards showing performance, liquidity status, uptime, and fees earned.

Alerts System: Automated notifications for downtime, low liquidity, or transaction bottlenecks.

Cross-Chain UX Layer

Wallet Integration: Orbit-compatible wallet extensions with one-click cross-chain swaps and transaction bundling.

dApp Integration SDK: Lightweight developer toolkit for integrating cross-chain UX features directly into Orbit dApps.

Transaction Optimizer: Aggregates liquidity and routes transactions through the most efficient solver pathways.

Analytics & Transparency Dashboard

Ecosystem Metrics: Transaction volumes, solver performance rankings, liquidity distribution, and Orbit chain usage trends.

User-Friendly Interface: Designed for developers, solvers, and end-users to track performance and trust metrics.

Public Data Access: Open APIs for ecosystem projects to build upon and extend analytics capabilities.

Implementation Plan & Milestones

Phase 1 – Research & Design (Month 1)

Finalize architecture for solver tooling, UX layer, and analytics.

Conduct user interviews with solvers and Orbit developers to refine features.

Design wireframes and system diagrams.

Phase 2 – MVP Development (Months 2–3)

Build Solver Dashboard (onboarding + basic monitoring).

Launch testnet-compatible wallet extension for cross-chain swaps.

Deploy a basic analytics tracker for transaction flow visibility.

Phase 3 – Testnet Deployment & User Testing (Months 4–5)

Release MVP on Orbit testnet for pilot solvers and developers.

Collect feedback and refine UI/UX.

Add alerts/notifications and developer SDK for dApp integration.

Phase 4 – Mainnet Launch (Month 6)

Deploy production-ready solver tools and wallet integration.

Launch full analytics dashboard with public APIs.

Conduct audits and finalize documentation for open-source release.

Phase 5 – Ecosystem Growth (Month 7+)

Partner with dApps and solver teams to expand adoption.

Add advanced features like solver reputation scores and transaction routing optimizations.

Continue maintenance and iterative improvements.

This structured plan ensures the project moves from concept → MVP → mainnet launch within six months, directly contributing to solver efficiency, cross-chain adoption, and transparency within the Arbitrum Orbit ecosystem.

applications.fundingAsk:
The Orbitscan – Unified Multi-Chain Explorer for the Arbitrum Orbit Ecosystem
The Arbitrum Orbit ecosystem now has 49+ active mainnet chains. While this growth is positive, it has created a fragmented experience — users must jump between multiple explorers to track activity.
Orbitscan will:
Aggregate and display data from 25 Orbit mainnet chains.


Let users connect a wallet to see balances, token holdings, and transaction histories across chains.


Provide both a web platform and mobile apps for iOS and Android.


Offer public APIs for developers building Orbit-based tools.


Key Features:
Unified Asset View — Total balance per chain, token breakdown, and last updated time.


Transaction History — Incoming/outgoing transactions with details (hash, type, block number, from/to, value, fees, gas used, transfer count).


Implementation Plan 
Phase 1 – Foundation & MVP Launch (Weeks 1–6)
Web: UI/UX design, frontend build, backend integration for first 8 chains.


Mobile: Architecture & feature outline for iOS/Android, initial UI mockups.


Phase 2 – Expansion & Feedback (Weeks 7–12)
Add 17 more chains (total 25).


Refine based on user feedback.


Begin full mobile development.


Phase 3 – Launch & Maintenance (Months 4–6)
Optimize, debug, and polish both web and mobile.


Publish apps on Google Play & Apple App Store.


Provide 3 months post-launch support.

Arbitrum Support 
As part of incentivizing further growth in the Arbitrum ecosystem, we’d love to secure support from OCL / Arbitrum to help these projects take structured next steps. Below are the key areas where this support would be valuable, and how we envision implementing it:

1. Projects Monetary Support

applications.fundingAsk:
dApp.fun is a decentralized platform that lets anyone build and tokenize full-stack Web3 dApps using just natural language prompts — no coding required.
dApp.fun empowers users to launch scalable, unrestricted dApps across any use case, with every project broken into  reusable modules assembled by verifiable AI powered by Eigen. The platform doesn’t just stop at deployment — it completes the Build → Tokenize → Validate → Fund lifecycle through a unique capital flywheel:
🔧 Build & Deploy (Modular): AI breaks each dApp into self-contained modules (Token, DAO, LP, DeFi, NFT, Frontend, Backend) with locked interfaces and signed provenance, ensuring reproducible builds and auditable code.
 💰 Tokenize: Each dApp can launch its own token + LP pool via an epoch-based launch structure.
 ✅ Milestone & Validation: Community validates each module and full project through traction, votes, LP depth, and performance metrics.
 🤖 AI Grant Agent: Platform AI allocates grants based on code quality, module verification results, and community interest.
 🧠 VC-AI Analyst Layer: Validated dApps are reviewed by AI agents of VC partners for LP injection and token allocation, giving everyday builders access to venture capital.
With modular builds, verifiable AI, and on-chain attestations, dApp.fun turns any idea into a funded, trust-verified Web3 business — all in one interface.

applications.fundingAsk:
We will build an open‑source Cross‑chain Error‑Debugger CLI for Arbitrum. When a cross‑layer transaction (L1 ↔ L2 ↔ Orbit L3) fails, the CLI traces every hop, identifies the exact failure point, and explains why it broke. It also replays the final call in a forked chain to decode the real revert reason; something current single‑chain debuggers do not provide.

Implementation Plan:

1. Layer‑Aware Trace Engine
    • Collects canonical‑bridge events, inbox/outbox logs, and retryable transaction data (current Arbitrum terminology).
    • Uses only public RPC endpoints; no private infrastructure needed.
    • Outputs an ordered timeline of the transaction across all layers.

2.    Failure Classification
    • Detects common issues such as retryable expiry, out‑of‑gas, un‑relayed messages, or nonce mismatches.
    • Returns a structured JSON + Markdown report with clear, descriptive error fields.

    Local Replay Module
    • Forks the relevant chain at the failure block using Foundry (anvil).
    • Re‑executes the calldata to surface and decode any ABI‑level revert message.
    • Provides a “dry‑run” flag so devs can reproduce the failure locally.

3.    CLI Interface
    • Single command: orbit‑debug <txHash> --network mainnet
    • Generates a shareable report without manual configuration—only standard RPC URLs.

4.    Documentation & Examples
    • Quick‑start guide, API reference, and a 5‑minute demo video.
    • Real test‑case examples from Orbit testnets (e.g., Xai, RariChain) included in the repo for reproducibility.

applications.grantAmount:
Yes, we have received 2 grants that directly supported the research and early development behind the Curvy Protocol:

Ethereum Foundation Academic Grant
This grant supported our research on more efficient stealth address protocol. The resulting papers (which can be found here https://docs.curvy.box/research-papers.html) form the cryptographic foundation for Curvy. These insights directly shaped the protocol’s design.

Starknet Foundation Seed Grant
We also received a seed grant from the Starknet Foundation to adapt the Curvy Protocol for the Starknet OS (Starknet Virtual Machine). This grant allowed us to begin exploring multi-chain deployment and helped validate Curvy’s flexibility across different execution environments.

applications.name: This project supports Arbitrum’s ecosystem growth by making it easier to discover and interact with ...
applications.fundingAsk:
We’re building the Orbit Chains Portal that is a lightweight, open-source frontend and registry that helps developers and users discover, interact with, and build on Orbit chains. While community-curated lists and scattered resources exist, there’s still no dedicated, user-friendly hub for navigating live Orbit chains, verified RPC endpoints, supported tokens, active dApps, or bridges. This lack of structure increases onboarding friction, slows developer workflows, and limits cross-chain activity.

Our portal solves this problem through a clear and modular system which includes a GitHub-governed backend registry of Orbit metadata (chain IDs, endpoints, explorers, tokens, etc.) and a frontend interface that renders each Orbit chain and dApp entry in a clean, actionable format. It makes interaction seamless by enabling developers and users to add chains (via wallet_addEthereumChain, EIP-3085), import tokens (wallet_watchAsset, EIP-747), and access verified bridge links. We’ll also run automated health checks to flag lagging or inactive endpoints and maintain community trust.

The full implementation plan includes:

- Schema design and registry setup (Week 1–2): Define JSON spec for chains, dApps, tokens, bridges; host registry on GitHub with PR workflow.

- Validation engine and RPC health check (Week 3–4): Create CLI tool to validate submissions, and run regular checks to flag slow or unsynced RPCs (10+ block lag or >60s delay).

- Frontend portal (Week 5–8): Build a fast, mobile-friendly web app (Next.js) for browsing Orbit chain metadata, verified links, and bridging options. Bridges default to Arbitrum TokenBridge, with third-party options like Orbiter or Wormhole when compatible.

- Community contribution flow (Week 9–10): Implement pull request preview system with clear contribution rules and moderation guidelines.

-  Launch and documentation (Week 11–12): Deploy portal, publish full technical docs, and announce contribution program.

We are fully committed to maintaining this tool post-grant with bug fixes, community support, and open governance. After this MVP, our next focus will be on integrating Orbit-specific tooling into the registry; like UI badges for intent-compatible dApps, or real-time metrics on solver presence per chain.

applications.fundingAsk:
We’re applying for a grant to build the Orbit Intent SDK and Solver Toolkit which is an open-source developer resource designed to make it easy for builders and liquidity providers to interact with the Universal Intent Engine (UIE) on Orbit chains.

As we are now, developers building on Orbit have no standard tooling for creating intents, handling off-chain logic, or setting up a solver. This leads to duplicated effort, bugs, and long setup cycles. Similarly, liquidity providers or cross-chain agents interested in running solvers face unnecessary friction—there’s no Orbit-native reference implementation or deployment guide tailored for the current state of UIE.This project solves both problems.

The SDK will offer:

- A lightweight, Orbit-focused TypeScript library for intent creation and submission, with full support for ERC-7683

- Built-in helpers for encoding intent payloads, managing signatures, and broadcasting to a canonical UIE feed (or fallback IPFS channel)

The solver toolkit will include:

- A minimal working solver client that listens for intent payloads, simulates outcomes, submits responses, and tracks transaction health

- A reference liquidity routing module with basic rebalancing logic

- Configuration tools and environment templates to reduce onboarding time

Implementation Plan:

- Week 1–2: Design spec, ERC-7683 compliance check, Orbit compatibility research

- Week 3–6: SDK development, including TS client, encoder, broadcaster

- Week 7–11: Solver client implementation with rebalancing module

- Week 12–15: Integration testing, doc writing, developer onboarding guides

- Week 16–20: Final audit prep, audit submission, public launch

applications.name:
1. Advancing DeFi Dominance
OrbitFlow directly supports Arbitrum's mission to be the leading DeFi ec...
applications.fundingAsk:
OrbitFlow is a real-time, cross-chain liquidity analytics platform purpose-built for the Arbitrum Orbit ecosystem. The platform is designed to bring visibility, transparency, and actionable intelligence to liquidity flows across Orbit-based chains, third-party bridges, and major DeFi protocols. In an increasingly fragmented on-chain environment, OrbitFlow aims to serve as the unified data layer that connects and contextualizes how capital moves across the ecosystem.

Problem Statement
Currently, liquidity across the Orbit ecosystem is dispersed across various rollups, bridge providers, and dApps. There’s no consolidated source to monitor or interpret this data efficiently. As a result:

Developers lack the tools to optimize cross-chain experiences.

DAOs and treasuries struggle with capital monitoring and allocation.

Liquidity providers can't assess real-time risks or optimize bridging strategies.

Ecosystem health and growth metrics are difficult to access or verify.

OrbitFlow’s Vision
OrbitFlow will solve these issues by offering:

Liquidity flow heatmaps showing directional capital movements across Orbit chains.

Bridge performance dashboards comparing fees, speeds, and reliability.

Real-time analytics for DeFi protocols and treasury wallets.

A developer-friendly API layer for integrating liquidity intelligence into dApps, governance tools, and dashboards.

A self-updating engine that detects and integrates newly launched Orbit chains automatically.

Implementation Plan
OrbitFlow will be developed in several stages, designed to evolve from a prototype into a production-grade analytics platform.

Phase 1: Research & Architecture Finalization
Finalize data schemas for representing liquidity flows, bridge events, and chain interactions.

Identify initial Orbit chains and bridge protocols to integrate.

Set up infrastructure requirements (indexers, APIs, database design, cloud hosting).

Phase 2: Data Ingestion & Indexing
Build custom indexers that listen to on-chain events on Orbit rollups.

Integrate APIs from key bridge providers to collect off-chain performance data.

Normalize and map data across chains and protocols into a unified format.

Phase 3: Analytics Engine & Dashboards
Develop analytics logic to compute metrics such as inflow/outflow, TVL shifts, bridge usage, and liquidity velocity.

Launch the first version of the dashboard featuring:

Chain-to-chain liquidity flow visualizations

Bridge comparison tables

Protocol-specific liquidity metrics

Phase 4: Developer API & Alerting System
Deploy a RESTful API layer enabling third parties to fetch liquidity data and analytics.

Introduce webhook-based alerts for notable events (e.g., large liquidity migrations, bridge congestion).

Publish documentation for dev integration.

Phase 5: Dynamic Chain Discovery & Scaling
Build a module that automatically identifies and integrates new Orbit chains using Arbitrum’s on-chain registry or metadata sources.

Expand coverage to additional chains, tokens, and protocols as the ecosystem grows.

How It Will Be Achieved
The development will be carried out by a small, highly technical team with expertise in blockchain indexing, analytics infrastructure, and frontend engineering. The backend will focus on real-time data pipelines and normalization across multiple data sources, while the frontend will prioritize usability and actionable design for developers, DAOs, and liquidity providers.

Data security and system performance will be top priorities, using robust cloud infrastructure and best practices for API rate-limiting, monitoring, and caching. By maintaining modularity, OrbitFlow will stay adaptable to future innovations within the Arbitrum and Orbit stack.

In essence, OrbitFlow aims to become the essential liquidity intelligence layer for Orbit, providing the insights necessary for strategic decision-making, risk assessment, and ecosystem-wide coordination. This grant would enable us to take the platform from ideation to MVP and begin delivering measurable value to the Arbitrum community.

applications.fundingAsk:
This is a decentralized art gallery and marketplace built on Ethereum and Arbitrum technologies including L3s (like Animechain).  This leverages cross-chain messaging and larger contract size limits to contribute to a more valuable art platform. Its mission is to empower artists with direct funding and visibility, leveraging existing NFT markets, while making it easy for web2 artists to join without needing to understand web3 complexities.  It also introduces an escrow bidding system for art demand which art demand transparent and more socialied.
Automatic Ownership Tracking for Commissioned Art
Commissioned Art "Galleries" link commissioned art to NFTs across blockchains (L1, L2, L3).
When an NFT is sold, ownership of related art in a gallery updates automatically via cross-chain messaging
Example: Buying an NFT on ApeChain updates its three attached art pieces (in a gallery) to the new owner
On-Chain Art Storage
Art can be stored directly on the blockchain (L2/L3), bypassing external services like IPFS.
Enabled by cost-effective storage and larger contract sizes (e.g., 45KB on Animechain L3). A test was proven by storing 10,000 Azuki images directly in smart contracts on-chain (
azukionchain.web.app
)

Direct and Automated Artist Support
Bidding Escrow System: Users can place bids for new art on an artists profile.  Escrow contracts can be pre filled with bids for art fostering direct market demand for artists and public leaderboards of said artist demand
ERC 1155/721 Tokens: Users may, of course, also mint digital prints of art they like (if the artist allows).  Minting original art or commissioned works on site.
100% Decentralized & Free
No fees, ever (100% of payments go to artists for all sales mechanisms)
Fully permissionless, with contract ownership planned to be revoked and all updates managed through a DAO.
User-Friendly for Web2 Artists
Email-based access (via tools like Privy) to help on-board web2 users. 
 Also this allows simple migration of web2 artist content.  UI keeps all actions simple like drag-and-drop uploads and gassless transactions (in certain cases) to hide web3 complexity.

applications.name: The Orbit Multi-Chain Dev Sandbox directly supports Arbitrum’s goals of ecosystem expansion and deve...
applications.fundingAsk:
We are applying for a grant to design, build, and release an open-source local development environment that allows users to spin up and interact with multiple Orbit chains on their own machines. This tool will simulate mainnet-like behavior, enable cross-chain testing, and significantly streamline development workflows for Orbit-native applications, solvers, and rollup deployments.

Implementation Plan:

1. Environment Orchestration Layer:
   Develop a CLI-based tool to configure and launch multiple Orbit chains locally using the Arbitrum Orbit SDK and Nitro node software. Each chain will run in a containerized or process-isolated environment with fully customizable parameters (chain ID, token settings, bridging configurations, etc.).

2. State Forking & Chain Simulation:
   Integrate support for forking an existing Orbit chain at any given block height, enabling testing against real-world contract state and history.

3. Cross-Chain Communication Setup:
   Implement message-passing and bridging simulation between chains using mock bridge contracts or standardized dev-mode bridge templates. This enables realistic testing of token transfers, governance messages, and other chain-to-chain interactions.

4. Hardhat Integration & Tooling:
   Provide a set of Hardhat plugins and deployment scripts to simplify multi-chain smart contract deployment and testing within the local environment.

5. Templates & Documentation:
   Offer boilerplate projects and comprehensive documentation to help developers get started with cross-chain dApp development and Orbit chain testing quickly.

6. Open Source Release & Community Feedback:
   Release the sandbox as a public GitHub repo and collect feedback from developers, validators, and solver teams to guide iterative improvements.

applications.name: TriggerX aligns with Arbitrum’s goals by providing decentralized automation for Arbitrum One and Orb...
applications.fundingAsk:
We are applying for a grant to support the completion and ecosystem rollout of **TriggerX**, a decentralized automation protocol designed to power trustless, programmable smart contract execution across the Arbitrum stack, particularly for **Orbit rollups**.

TriggerX enables developers to schedule and execute smart contract actions based on the following triggers:

- **Time-based intervals** such as hourly updates, daily emissions, or epoch-driven changes
- **On-chain events**, including governance proposals, oracle price changes, or contract calls
- **Custom logic and thresholds** such as vault rebalancing, liquidity shifts, or DAO-defined parameters
- **Off-chain context and AI-generated decisions**, through direct integration with the **Model Context Protocol (MCP)**

The protocol operates via a decentralized **Keeper Network**, where registered nodes monitor and execute registered tasks. These jobs are validated by an on-chain **Aggregator**, which ensures execution correctness and consensus, while slashing underperforming or malicious actors when necessary.

**Focus on Orbit Chains:** 
While Arbitrum Orbit provides a modular framework for deploying custom L3 rollups, these rollups currently launch without native infrastructure for automation. TriggerX fills this gap by enabling Orbit chains to access a production-grade automation protocol through minimal configuration. Builders only need to deploy a lightweight `TaskManager` contract and register basic chain metadata in the backend. This removes the need for dedicated backend infrastructure, centralized automation bots, or chain-specific scheduling code.

**Current Status:**
The protocol is already live on testnet with support for time-, event-, and condition-based automation. Interlinked job workflows and partially decentralized keeper functionality are also live. We are currently testing real-world automation flows with several of the largest EigenLayer operators, including **EigenYields** and **P2P.org**. Operator participation can be verified through the testnet aggregator interface:
https://holesky.eigenlayer.xyz/avs/0xE52De62Bf743493d3c4E1ac8db40f342FEb11fEa/operator-set/4294967295

**Implementation Plan:**

1. **Orbit Chain Integration**
Finalize the Orbit onboarding module by enabling config-based registration, lightweight deployment (TaskManager only), and Orbit-aware CLI and SDK tooling.
2. **MCP Integration**
Complete the Model Context Protocol integration to allow AI agents to trigger Orbit chain automation. Deliver example agent workflows and agent-to-chain execution demos.
3. **Keeper Reward and Slashing Logic**
Implement and simulate slashing for inactive or misbehaving keepers. Publish reward distribution logs and system telemetry on testnet.
4. **Mainnet Deployment on Arbitrum One**
Deploy the fully audited version of the core contracts to Arbitrum One. Release the UI/CLI tools, Keeper portal, job monitoring system, and user onboarding documentation.
5. **Developer SDK and Orbit Onboarding Toolkit**
Deliver TypeScript and Go SDKs, CLI support, configuration templates, and implementation documentation to help Orbit developers adopt TriggerX with minimal overhead.

TriggerX is built to serve the future of modular appchains on Arbitrum. This grant will allow us to productionize infrastructure that is already live and extend it to Orbit chains that need secure, decentralized automation from day one.
applications.grantAmount:
Yes. While TriggerX has not received any external grants specific to long-term development, we have participated in ecosystem hackathons and received limited funding through awards.

Currently, TriggerX is incubated at [Lampros Tech](https://lampros.tech/), and all development and operational costs have been funded internally. Team members have contributed to their own capacity to build and maintain the infrastructure, smart contracts, and initial deployments.

Additionally:

- We participated in the AVS MicroHacks Hackathon hosted by EigenLayer, where we built a decentralized Keeper network as part of an AVS reference design. This work later evolved into the foundation of TriggerX. Our project ranked 5th overall and received a $2,500 award.
([Winner announcement tweet](https://x.com/buildoneigen/status/1804495302746841160))
- We also participated in the TRON Season 7 HackaTRON, where we were awarded 2nd place in the DeFi track under the community-selected winners category. This was an early experiment, which helped validate our direction for TriggerX. We received $6,000 as the track prize for ranking 2nd. ([Winners Announcement Post](https://forum.trondao.org/t/hackatron-s7-qualifiers-and-winners-list/29669/3))

In parallel, two team members (Aakash and Prapti) are currently contributing to [Speedrun Stylus](https://arbitrum.questbook.app/dashboard/?chainId=10&proposalId=67e6a57416e7410ad76b9d7e&role=community&isRenderingProposalBody=true&grantId=67d8021646da2f90cc325521), a separate developer onboarding and engagement platform focused on expanding adoption of Arbitrum’s Stylus tooling.

applications.fundingAsk:
L{Core} IoT SDK is a privacy-focused IoT developer toolkit for Arbitrum’s Stylus and Orbit environments, designed to bring real-world data on-chain without centralized oracles. By combining zkProofs, Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE), and on-chain deterministic SQLite databases, the SDK allows developers to securely process micro-level sensor data directly in Stylus contracts in a decentralized way. This approach supports a broad range of real-world use cases—such as small business lending, decentralized insurance, and local government services on Orbit chains—while ensuring user privacy and trust. Through the open-source “City-Chains” model, we aim to onboard entire communities to Arbitrum, helping them leverage real-time data and transparent liquidity in areas previously excluded from Web3.

applications.name: Kurtosis-Orbit simplifies Orbit chain deployment to a single command, dramatically reducing technica...
applications.fundingAsk:
I am proposing to develop Kurtosis-Orbit, a one-command development environment for Arbitrum Orbit chains. The project will create a Kurtosis package that automatically deploys and configures a complete Orbit chain stack – including an Ethereum L1 node, Arbitrum Nitro sequencer and validators, token bridges, and supporting services – all within an isolated Docker-based environment.

The core idea is to drastically simplify the Orbit chain development process by providing:

1. A single command to deploy a fully functional private Orbit chain (L2)
2. Parameterized configuration for customizing chain behavior (block time, gas token, etc.)
3. Isolated environments that can be easily torn down and recreated
4. Integration with standard development workflows and tools

The package will be open-sourced on GitHub with comprehensive documentation, making it accessible to the entire Arbitrum community. It will support Rollup configurations, allowing developers to experiment with different performance settings in a safe environment.

By creating this tool, I aim to accelerate the adoption of Arbitrum Orbit by making it significantly easier for developers to experiment with and build on custom Orbit chains. This aligns perfectly with the Arbitrum Foundation's goal of expanding the ecosystem through Orbit chains.
